repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body:
There is still a warning:

```
warning: test.pyx:3:18: Non-trivial type declarators in shared declaration (e.g. mix of pointers and values). Each pointer declaration should be on its own line.
```

```suggestion
                cdef float f
                cdef float[42] g
                cdef float *h
                # cdef float f, g[42], *h  # mix of pointers, arrays and values in a single line is deprecated
```

In addition, it would be better to explicitly mention the (soft-deprecated) C style declaration and Java style declaration in the documentaion.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -88,7 +88,8 @@ define global C variables.
 
             def func():
                 cdef int i, j, k
-                cdef float f, g[42], *h
+                cdef float f, *h
+                cdef float[42] g

comment_data.body:
```suggestion

        Cython currently supports two ways to declare an array:

        .. code-block:: cython

            cdef int arr1[4], arr2[4]  # C style array declaration
            cdef int[4] arr1, arr2     # Java style array declaration

        Both of them generate the same C code, but the Java style is more
        consistent with :ref:`memoryviews` and :ref:`fusedtypes`. The C style
        declaration is soft-deprecated and it's recommended to use Java style
        declaration instead.

```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -88,7 +88,10 @@ define global C variables.
 
             def func():
                 cdef int i, j, k
-                cdef float f, g[42], *h
+                cdef float f
+                cdef float[42] g
+                cdef float *h
+                # cdef float f, g[42], *h  # mix of pointers, arrays and values in a single line is deprecated
 
                 i = j = 5

comment_data.body:
``` suggestion

        The soft-deprecated C style array declaration doesn't support
        initialization.

        .. code-block:: cython

            cdef int g[4] = [1, 2, 3, 4]  # error

            cdef int[4] g = [1, 2, 3, 4]  # OK

            cdef int g[4]        # OK but not recommended
            g = [1, 2, 3, 4]
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -124,8 +127,7 @@ the declaration in most cases:
             def func():
                 cdef int i = 10, j, k
                 cdef float f = 2.5
-                # cdef float g[4] = [1,2,3,4]  # currently not supported
-                cdef float *g = [1, 2, 3, 4]
+                cdef int[4] g = [1, 2, 3, 4]
                 cdef float *h = &f

comment_data.body: I like your suggestions but if you are not against, I would move it to separate sections
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -88,7 +88,10 @@ define global C variables.
 
             def func():
                 cdef int i, j, k
-                cdef float f, g[42], *h
+                cdef float f
+                cdef float[42] g
+                cdef float *h
+                # cdef float f, g[42], *h  # mix of pointers, arrays and values in a single line is deprecated
 
                 i = j = 5

comment_data.body: These 4 blank lines can be removed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -152,6 +153,59 @@ the declaration in most cases:
 
                 ctypedef int* IntPtr
 
+C Arrays
+--------
+
+C array can be declared by adding ``[ARRAY_SIZE]`` to the type of variable:
+
+.. tabs::
+
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+        .. code-block:: python
+
+            def func():
+                g: cython.float[42]
+                f: cython.int[5][5][5]
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. code-block:: cython
+
+            def func():
+                cdef float[42] g
+                cdef int[5][5][5] f
+
+.. note::
+
+    Cython syntax currently supports two ways to declare an array:
+
+    .. code-block:: cython
+
+        cdef int arr1[4], arr2[4]  # C style array declaration
+        cdef int[4] arr1, arr2     # Java style array declaration
+
+    Both of them generate the same C code, but the Java style is more
+    consistent with :ref:`memoryviews` and :ref:`fusedtypes`. The C style
+    declaration is soft-deprecated and it's recommended to use Java style
+    declaration instead.
+
+    The soft-deprecated C style array declaration doesn't support
+    initialization.
+
+    .. code-block:: cython
+
+        cdef int g[4] = [1, 2, 3, 4]  # error
+
+        cdef int[4] g = [1, 2, 3, 4]  # OK
+
+        cdef int g[4]        # OK but not recommended
+        g = [1, 2, 3, 4]
+
+
+
+
+

commit.message: Move array documentation to separate section

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Softdeprecated C style array declaration in favour of Java style declaration
